intro: Gyrinopsis pubifolia, commonly known as the hairy sea holly, is a flowering plant native to coastal regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its distinctive blue or purple flowers and hairy, succulent leaves that help it retain moisture in arid environments. The plant belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is well adapted to sandy or rocky soils. Its unique morphology allows it to thrive in harsh coastal conditions, making it a notable species in maritime ecosystems. Gyrinopsis pubifolia is often found in dunes and along the edges of the ocean, where it plays a role in stabilizing sand and supporting local biodiversity.
